definitions.definition: To put a load on or in (a means of conveyance or a place of storage).
examples: The dock workers refused to load the ship.

definitions.definition: To place in or on a conveyance or a place of storage.
examples: The longshoremen loaded the cargo quickly.
He loaded his stuff into his storage locker.

definitions.definition: To put a load on something.
examples: The truck was supposed to leave at dawn, but in fact we spent all morning loading .

definitions.definition: To receive a load.
examples: The truck is designed to load easily.

definitions.definition: To be placed into storage or conveyance.
examples: The containers load quickly and easily.

definitions.definition: To fill (a firearm or artillery) with munition .
examples: I pulled the trigger, but nothing happened. I had forgotten to load the gun.

definitions.definition: To insert (an item or items) into an apparatus so as to ready it for operation, such as a reel of film into a camera, sheets of paper into a printer etc.
examples: Now that you've loaded the film [into the camera], you're ready to start shooting.
Now that you've loaded the camera [with film], you're ready to start shooting.

definitions.definition: To fill (an apparatus) with raw material.
examples: The workers loaded the blast furnace with coke and ore.

definitions.definition: To be put into use in an apparatus.
examples: The cartridge was designed to load easily.

definitions.definition: To read ( data or a program ) from a storage medium into computer memory.
examples: Click OK to load the selected data.

definitions.definition: To transfer from a storage medium into computer memory.
examples: This program takes an age to load .

definitions.definition: To put runners on first , second and third bases
examples: He walks to load the bases.

definitions.definition: To tamper with so as to produce a biased outcome .
examples: You can load the dice in your favour by researching the company before your interview.
The wording of the ballot paper loaded the vote in favour of the Conservative candidate.

definitions.definition: To ask or adapt a question so that it will be more likely to be answered in a certain way.
To encumber with something negative, to place as an encumbrance.
examples: The new owners had loaded the company with debt.
The new owners loaded debt on the company.

definitions.definition: To provide in abundance.
examples: He loaded his system with carbs before the marathon.
He loaded carbs into his system before the marathon.

definitions.definition: To weight (a cane, whip, etc.) with lead or similar.
To adulterate or drug .
examples: to load wine

definitions.definition: To magnetize .
to top up or purchase phone credits

main_definition: ( transitive ) To put a load on or in (a means of conveyance or a place of storage).
secondary_definitions: ( transitive ) To place in or on a conveyance or a place of storage.
( intransitive ) To put a load on something.
( intransitive ) To be placed into storage or conveyance.
( transitive ) To fill (a firearm or artillery) with munition .
( transitive ) To insert (an item or items) into an apparatus so as to ready it for operation, such as a reel of film into a camera, sheets of paper into a printer etc.
( transitive ) To fill (an apparatus) with raw material.
( intransitive ) To be put into use in an apparatus.
( transitive , computing ) To read ( data or a program ) from a storage medium into computer memory.
( intransitive , computing ) To transfer from a storage medium into computer memory.
( transitive , baseball ) To put runners on first , second and third bases
( transitive ) To tamper with so as to produce a biased outcome .
( transitive ) To ask or adapt a question so that it will be more likely to be answered in a certain way.
( transitive ) To encumber with something negative, to place as an encumbrance.
( transitive ) To weight (a cane, whip, etc.) with lead or similar.
( transitive , archaic , slang ) To adulterate or drug .
( Philippines ) to top up or purchase phone credits
